column3:
• 70% of the staterooms have private balconies. All cabins are exterior, enabling you to enjoy the spectacular Antarctic views
  • Two jacuzzis and an onboard sauna allow you to warm up in style after a chilly day out exploring on foot and by zodiac
  • Safe navigation of challenging polar waters - top ice class 1A/PC6 rating
  • Advanced "clean ship" engines with significantly lower emissions than traditional expedition vessels
  • X-Bow® Infinity technology and zero speed stabilisers on a purpose-built expedition ship improves your comfort in rough waters
  • Optional activities include kayaking, snowshoeing and camping for active travellers

column55: Lizzie Williams says - I sailed aboard Ocean Victory in February 2022 and loved waking up to panoramic views of sculptural icebergs and jagged glaciated mountains through the floor-to-ceiling balcony doors.  A perfect way to start the day!

column3:
• The first sub-100 passenger ship engineered for Antarctic expeditionary cruising since its sister vessel, the Magellan Explorer, launched in 2019
  • Limited to just 76 passengers per fly-cruise voyage for the most intimate expeditions around the White Continent
  • Designed by the pioneers of Antarctic fly-cruising, with an easy-access bow bringing you closer to the awe-inspiring scenery while sailing

column55: says - We’re delighted to see this new addition to the polar fleet combining over 20 years of Antarctic experience with environmentally-sensitive advances in maritime technology to enhance small scale expedition cruising.

column3:
• Designed and operated by the original pioneers of the Antarctic Fly & Cruise concept
  • Spacious, well appointed suites, many with floor-to-ceiling windows and outside balconies
  • Built to the latest Polar Code specifications, she carries a Polar Class 6 ice-class (Lloyd’s Register PC6)
  • For passenger comfort, the ship features state-of-the-art stabilisers
  • To minimise fuel consumption, a waste heat recovery system recycles the heat produced by the ship’s engines and repurposes it to power the ship’s heating system and to warm the water used on board

column55: says - I was thrilled to sail on and thoroughly inspect the Magellan Explorer in December 2021. The eye-catching design looks stunning amidst the ice and the small passenger capacity meant my experience of Antarctica was incredibly intimate, maximising my time exploring off the ship.

column3:
• A maximum of only 67 passengers ensures a very intimate polar experience and that everyone can get ashore together
  • Combines clean, comfortable Scandinavian styling, with a true expeditionary spirit
  • Ocean Nova's large expeditionary staff of 12 means the highest passenger to staff ratio of any Antarctic ship
  • A high ice class rating, outstanding manoeuvrability and a first rate captain allow Ocean Nova to access places other ships simply can't reach
  • The panoramic lounge with its 200 degree views is a popular place for wildlife viewing while keeping warm
  • Delicious hand picked Chilean wine is complimentary with meals
  • One of the few small ships with dedicated Single cabins, as well as Twins and Triple cabins, all with a picture window and en-suite bathroom

• As a petite ship, there is limited outside deck space
  • The twin cabins are some of the smallest in the polar fleet. Perfectly fine for sleeping and changing, but limited space for relaxing in
  • Originally built as a Greenland ferry, this ship is affected more than others in the fleet by adverse weather
column55: Alex Mudd says - I really like Ocean Nova and not just because she carried me across the Antarctic Circle. Hanging out in the panoramic lounge conveniently close to the killer coffee machine watching icebergs slip by, or a pod of orcas on the hunt one morning, was my idea of heaven.

column3:
• The revolutionary X-bow design helps the ship pierce through waves, reducing pitching to help maximise your comfort at sea
  • A maximum of just 130 passengers on board and a well-stocked fleet of sturdy zodiac ribs ensure you get off the ship as often as possible
  • 79% of the spacious cabins feature balconies with large floor-to-ceiling glass doors, so Antarctica’s stunning landscapes are always in your line of sight
  • For active explorers, the ship offers immersive optional activities including camping, snorkelling and kayaking
  • Thoughtful amenities include a purpose-built lecture theatre and Citizen Science Centre for the ship’s excellent educational programming
  • Two outdoor Jacuzzis and a sauna are on hand for defrosting after a busy day out exploring in the snow

column55: says - We’re delighted with this new addition to the expedition fleet. Built specifically for polar cruising, the smart design of the Douglas Mawson ensures an optimal experience both on and off the ship.

column3:
• The first expedition ship to pioneer the groundbreaking X-bow technology, it will pierce waves making for a smoother overall voyage
  • We love the fact that in spite of being crammed with technology, this petite ship carries a maximum of 130 passengers, ensuring an intimate atmosphere and smooth landing operations
  • 80% of the cabins benefit from having outer balconies and all are spaciously proportioned, ranging from 180 - 385 square feet
  • A panoramic observation deck with floor to ceiling windows and spacious outer decks means you’ll never miss out on the action wherever you are on the ship
  • For active travellers, optional activities are available: kayaking, camping, snowshoeing, scuba diving & polar snorkelling

column3:
• The sleek X-bow is designed with passengers' comfort in mind, reducing pitching and allowing the ship to cut through the waves
  • One of the smaller polar expedition ships, with a maximum of 130 passengers, this allows for speedy disembarkation and to maximise your time exploring off-ship
  • Most cabins have balconies and all are generously proportioned with large windows, so you never miss a spectacular vista
  • An impressive range of optional add-on activities are available, from kayaking and camping to polar snorkelling!
  • An unusual double height glass atrium in the bow floods the expedition lounge with polar light
  • Two jacuzzis and a sauna help you to warm up after a chilly day out exploring

column55: Alex Mudd Says - I really like this ship's style. Its bright red colouring looks fantastic amongst Antarctica's icebergs, it's one of the most spacious ships in the polar fleet and the expedition staff really know their stuff. A proper expedition vessel with all the kit and caboodle that goes with that.

column3:
• The ship’s generous proportions means all 140 passengers have ample space
  • Carries one of the highest ice class ratings (Lloyds A1s) and is fully compliant with the new Polar Code
  • Very spacious cabins, far more generous than most polar ships - from 250 sq feet (22m) - 474 sq feet (44m)
  • Large observation lounges and a choice of two dining rooms all offer panoramic views
  • Features a well-equipped gym, spa, sauna and steam room
  • Modern stabilising unit ensures a more comfortable ride in the Southern Ocean

column3:
• The 2022 renovation upgraded cabins, suites and public areas, including a signature science center, and there's a choice of two restaurants
  • The light-filled observation lounge and bar features vast wrap-around panoramic windows for enjoying the glorious Antarctic views
  • The well-equipped gym has yet another panoramic ocean view; an indoor sauna and outdoor hot tubs round out the wellness facilities
  • Professional expedition guides are on hand in the thoughtfully designed lecture theatre to help you deepen your Antarctic knowledge
  • Though it has space for 250 guests, capacity in Antarctica is capped at 200 onboard, meaning there’s plenty of room in the social areas and out on deck

column55: says - We love the extensive bow space on Deck 5. It's perfect for photographers and those wanting to experience the spectacular landscapes and wildlife of Antarctica. The handy covered side walkways provide some welcome shelter if it's snowing or windy on the bow.

column3:
• The competitively priced ship's expansive interior comfortably welcomes up to 500 passengers across a range of spacious outside cabins, half of which have private balconies
  • A one-of-a-kind science centre features a range of microscopes, large screens for showcasing gathered samples and even some skeletal replicas of polar wildlife
  • Fun art workshops allow you to produce clay, ink and paint creations inspired by your Antarctic travels
  • Enjoy wellness facilities such as an outdoor walking track, window-lined saunas, outdoor hot tubs and a plunge pool – all with mesmerising polar views
  • Three onboard restaurants mean there’s always a meal to please your palate
  • This quiet, hybrid-powered ship is plastic-free, reducing its impact on the environment

  • The ship doesn't have an open bridge policy, though there is usually the chance for a short tour at some point in your expedition
column55: Lizzie Williams says - This was my first experience of travelling on a hybrid power expedition ship and I was blown away by the silent sailing moments, especially when whale watching out on the expansive decks. It was magical!

column3:
• This competitively priced ship comfortably hosts up to 500 guests in a wide choice of spacious outside cabins, half of which have private balconies
  • The unique science centre is equipped with multiple microscopes, large screens to show collected samples and even skeletal casts of various polar species
  • Unusual craft workshops allow guests to capture their Antarctic experience in clay, ink and paint
  • To relax between activities, warm up in the window-lined saunas take a dip in the outdoor hot tubs and plunge pool, or stroll around the outdoor walking track
  • With three restaurants onboard, there's always a choice of cuisine to suit your mood
  • Sustainability minded initiatives such as banning single-use plastic and silent sailing using battery power help reduce the impact of your expedition

  • Retractable gyroscopic stabilising fins help reduce roll by 70-80%, while the strengthened bows to the highest 1A categorisation maximise safety in icy waters
  • A dedicated mudroom and dual zodiac loading areas ensure slick and speedy logistics and no waiting time during zodiac operations
  • Superior onboard safety features, including ice radar and forward-scanning sonar help identify uncharted obstacles and the safest routes
  • The panoramic Observation Lounge & library are very popular places with all guests
  • An onboard ROV capturing rare underwater footage and photographic gear available for loan by guests are both unique to this ship

From her stunning panoramic observation lounge to the retractable stabilisers, and even photo equipment which you can loan, they've thought of everything. Then throw in some of the best expedition staff in the business.

column3:

  • Each cabin features a window for uninterrupted views of Antarctica from the comfort of your personal space
  • Onboard wellness facilities include a sauna, gym, spa treatment room and an outdoor Jacuzzi
  • The ship has carefully considered public spaces, including informal dining and a window-filled observation lounge with a bar and lecture facilities
  • As you explore, the onboard undersea specialist pilots a remotely operated vehicle to share unique footage of Antarctica’s underwater world with guests

column3:
• Ortelius has the highest ice-class rating (equivalent to 1A) and a broad, heavy design making it one of the safest and most stable polar ships
  • Her solid, former research vessel exterior contrasts with a modern, comfortable 3* hotel on the inside following an extensive upgrade programme
  • Choice of recently refurbished and spacious cabins, all with en-suite bathrooms. The generous Twin Window cabins measure 190 square feet
  • Traveling with around 100 passengers ensures slick zodiac logistics and the ability to normally land everyone at the same time
  • Extensive open-deck space maximises wildlife viewing, while the spacious bridge is a great place to hang out
  • Offers a wide range of adventure activities, particularly on the active Basecamp voyages, including diving
  • Uniquely this ship has a helicopter pad which is used on select voyages only, specifically in the Weddell & Ross Seas

column55: Alex Mudd says - What I like about The Ortelius is the unmistakable tang of her original working ship roots as soon as you board, in spite of extensive recent refurbishment throughout. The pleasing result is the feeling of being on a real expedition, but without the traditional discomfort and months at sea.

column3:
• Following the ship’s rebuild she combines the authenticity of an expedition ship on the outside with the comfort and amenities of a well-appointed 3* hotel on the inside
  • The ship's diesel-electric propulsion system greatly reduces noise and vibration, making the journey more comfortable, particularly at night
  • A wide choice of different cabin types, including Triples & Quads, all are modern with en-suite bathrooms and flat screen TVs with streamed movies
  • Twin gangways on the starboard side allows two zodiacs to be loaded at once which ensures minimal waiting time during embarkation and disembarkation
  • Stunning panorama views through the large windows of the observation lounge mean you won’t miss out on wildlife sightings while keeping warm onboard
  • Offers a wide range of adventure activities, particularly on the active Basecamp voyages, including being one of the few ships to offer diving

column55: Alex Mudd says - I'm always pleased when customers ask me about the Plancius as it's one of my favourites. I like its modern, contemporary styling - comfortable without being fussy - and guests always appreciate the quiet engines, particularly when sailing overnight. Thumbs up.

column3:
• With the highest ice-class rating available (1A Super) this ship is perfectly suited to safely exploring challenging polar waters
  • The vessel's speedy average cruising speed of 13.5 knots means less time at sea and more time exploring
  • Capped at a maximum 139 guests, even though it was originally built for 180, so there's plenty of space and you can always find a quiet spot
  • Large picture windows in the dining room mean you can enjoy spectacular Antarctic views as you sip complimentary drinks such as wines and beers
  • A variety of deck spaces to soak up the glorious landscape from every angle and take uninterrupted photos
  • A state-of-the-art stabilising system increases comfort in open water
  • A dedicated Citizen Science lab for those keen to dig deeper

  • Dedicated 'ready rooms' and multiple zodiac embarkation points mean there's no waiting to get on land
